dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Our topic today is gonna be quantum sensing. Have you ever heard of it before?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: No. Okay, what do you think it might mean, if you just break down the words?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Something on a very small scale because of the word quantum.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: The sensing part, I'm not sure.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: So sensing is really just about measuring stuff.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Okay.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: And at some level, there's different set of rules that seem to come into play 'cause you can have particles at very microscopic scales seem to do really strange things. But one of the quests of quantum sensing is to harvest some of these unique properties at the micro scale. We are really interested in quantum sensors because we think they can give us the ultimate limit of sensitivity. So they're really, really sensitive to small changes, but they're also gonna be really reliable. Every time I make that measurement, I'll always get the same results.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Okay, measurements on like what kinds of things?

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Could be on almost anything you want. Have you ever broken a bone?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Well, I fractured something though.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Okay, do you remember having an x-ray?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yeah, x-ray and I have had a few MRIs before too.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: You've had a few MRIs before.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: And so, both of those are in some ways a form of sensing and they rely on different types of sensing. Do you know what this image is?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Maybe an MRI.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Exactly. Yeah. Do you know what an MRI, how an MRI works?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: No, I don't and I feel like I should because I've gotten them millions of times.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: And what the MRI scanner is doing is, it's measuring the signal from all the water molecules that are present and specifically the hydrogen atom. In our bodies, we have these hydrogen atoms that are essentially spinning around magnetic fields all the time and we just don't know them. So in some sense, you've already used a quantum sensor.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yeah, so are MRIs essentially more detailed x-rays?

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: They're not.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Okay.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: So this is an x-ray. You don't see any of the soft tissue. The x-ray gave us information about the bone.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: [Julia] Yeah.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Whereas MRIs giving us information about things like the softer tissues.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: And in fact, we don't see the bone very well in the MRI.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: So there are slightly different reasons why you would choose the two different things. Suppose I could get a higher resolution.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Mm-hmm.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: What do you think I would be able to see?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: The different atoms and the structures of the particles. Yeah.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Start to see the different cells

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: And then the different chemicals in the cells. If you look at the MRI images, you can see that they give you the broad features of what the tissue looks like. But if you wanna zoom in a little bit more and see what's actually happening inside a tissue or inside a cell and you need a different type of sensor that's gonna be more sensitive and for something like that, you're gonna need a quantum sensor.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Are there different types of quantum sensors for different things?

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: So one of the quantum sensors that's related to the work that I do is based on these defects that are called nitrogen-vacancy centers

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Okay.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: In a diamond and people actually now make nano diamonds that they can try to put inside the human body to look at the chemistry inside the cells.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: So is that used for drug trials and when testing out new treatments?

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: We can do it on tissues right now or on the surface, but we can't actually do it inside the body. So right now, we're struggling to figure out which scenarios can we use this to get better information and when can we not do it.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Are there any other quantum sensors at the moment that are in the developmental stage anymore that we are using?

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: So there are quantum sensors that are sold for very specific applications, one of them is a magnetometer and those can be really, really sensitive to measure small variations in magnetic fields. They are trying to develop sensors that are gravitational sensors. Right now, we have no way of probing what's under the ground without digging into the ground.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: You talked about a sensor measuring magnetic fields.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: What does that help us learn? What is that good for?

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Well, if I wanna navigate, and I know what the structure of the Earth's magnetic fields are, in some ways, that's how birds navigate.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Okay.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: The avian compass.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: In fact, people think of that as a quantum sensor.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Okay, so they've got like built-in.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: A biological quantum sensor.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: They have a built-in sensor and one of the ideas is that, they're using quantum phenomena

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: To figure out what the direction of the Earth's magnetic field is.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Okay.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: That's why they're able to be, homing pigeons are able to come back

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: To their original location.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Oh, that's cool. Yeah.
